Work

My work

Prior to my current role as a Senior Product Designer at Carbon Five, I was principal UX designer and information architect at Media Temple, a web hosting and support provider based in Los Angeles. By its nature web hosting is highly technical, but I took pride in making interactions with our products easy and delightful for users.

I've been lucky to work on a wide range of cool projects like:

  • Multiple responsive websites with over a million views a month, including Media Temple's website and its AccountCenter.
  • A responsive, animated ad appearing on CodePen.
  • A mission-critical LiveChat sales and support widget.
  • A sales-generating tool to help business owners analyze their website's performance.

Read some case studies below and reach out to me @theJayBeeWhy if you find anything interesting.

WordPress Hosting

Case study: UX research, Information Architecture, and UI design

When Media Temple improved their WordPress hosting platform with a new on-boarding flow and a slate of new features, I had the opportunity to seriously reevaluate the product’s UX. I designed a friendly on-boarding process, reorganized the navigation and features in the control panel, and planned the product’s information architecture to accommodate future features.

Read more →

Google Apps Hosting Package

Case study: UX research, information architecture, and UI design

Media Temple released a hosting package that integrates Google Apps for Work – a one-stop shop for setting up a web presence. From the Media Temple control panel, a user can set up both a website and their company’s Google Apps service at the same time, all with a unique domain name. I designed an on-boarding experience and control panel UI that makes this entire process simple.

Read more →

Community KnowledgeBase

UX Research, Wireframes

The Media Temple KnowledgeBase is a curated library of self-help articles maintained by our Community Support team. It was due for a front-end update and I took the opportunity to improve its UX. I considered the existing KnowledgeBase's strengths, interpreted Google Analytics data, and evaluated the Zendesk API capabilities to improve layout and content hierarchy. Users can now more readily find the content they're searching and browsing for.

Left: My wireframes. Right: Full-fidelity visual design.

Left: My wireframes. Right: Full-fidelity visual design.

Shopping Cart and Checkout Flow

UX Research, Wireframes, UI Design

Media Temple recently rebuilt its purchase process site-wide in order to accommodate a traditional "shopping cart" style checkout process, as well as a brand-new log-in/sign-up step, both of which were lacking in previous iterations. I leveraged my knowledge of our back-end processes to create a flow that users were familiar with, while introducing new steps like mid-checkout authentication.

Above: The user flow from front-of-site, through purchase, to the start of on-boarding.

Left: My wireframes. Right: Full-fidelity visual design.

Info

Justin Barr Young is a product designer pushing pixels and code in sunny Los Angeles. He's been working, learning, and mentoring in the sweet spot where design and dev meet since 2006. Currently, he’s a Product Designer at Carbon Five. In his (rare) time away from his computer, he's out gardening, sampling local beers, reading nonfiction, or making sandwiches.

He built this site using LESS, Jekyll, CodeKit, and parts of Novastrap by @itsmeara.
